summary: A press release from the legal/media team of Prince Andrew (HRH The Duke of York) responding to public statements by the U.S. Department of Justice. It asserts that Prince Andrew has offered cooperation as a witness three times in 2020, contradicts claims of 'zero cooperation,' and criticizes the DOJ for breaching confidentiality rules.

events.title: First DOJ Request for Cooperation
events.description: The US Department of Justice first requested Prince Andrew's help in their investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's victims.

events.title: Berman's First Public Statement
events.description: U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman made a public statement leading to worldwide media reports of a 'wall of silence' and 'zero cooperation' from Prince Andrew.

events.title: Berman's Second Public Statement
events.description: Berman stated Prince Andrew had 'completely shut the door' on cooperating and that the DOJ was 'considering' further options.

events.title: Release of Clarifying Statement
events.description: Prince Andrew's legal team issues a press release to correct the record, stating he has made three offers to cooperate as a witness in 2020.

keyFacts: Prince Andrew's legal team states he is not and has never been a 'target' of the DOJ's criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.
The Duke of York's team claims he has offered to cooperate as a witness to the DOJ on at least three occasions in 2020.
The press release accuses the DOJ, specifically U.S. Attorney Geoffrey Berman, of breaching confidentiality rules and making inaccurate public statements about Andrew's lack of cooperation.
Andrew's team asserts the DOJ gave an 'unequivocal assurance' that discussions and any interview would remain confidential, an assurance they claim was breached.
The legal working group for Prince Andrew includes law firm Blackfords LLP, counsel Clare Montgomery QC and Stephen Ferguson, and media relations firm Riverside Advisory.
